title: Inside a Sequencing Lab on the Front Lines of America’s Search for Omicron
content: More states are finding cases of the new variant. Tracking its spread, experts say, is key to understanding what threat it poses.

title: Cognitive Rehab: One Patient’s Painstaking Path Through Long Covid Therapy
content: Samantha Lewis is relearning some basic aspects of her daily life after struggling with brain fog and other lingering symptoms for more than a year since being infected by the virus.

more_info.byline: By Pam Belluck and Alex Wroblewski

title: Upstate New York Hospitals Are Overwhelmed as Covid Cases Surge
content: Health care officials say a “perfect storm” of new Covid cases, staff shortages and filled nursing homes has created a crisis.

title: Facing Charges, Parents of Michigan Shooting Suspect Are Now Fugitives
content: Prosecutors charged the parents of the 15-year-old accused of killing four classmates with involuntary manslaughter, saying they failed to act on troubling signs.

title: Read the Prosecutor’s Remarks on Charging the Michigan Suspect’s Parents
content: In a news conference, the prosecutor in Oakland County, Mich., detailed what led the county to criminally charge the parents of the student accused of killing four classmates.

title: November Jobs Report Shows Weak Hiring but a Surge in the Labor Force
content: Employers reported adding 210,000 jobs, the year’s weakest showing, but there were also bright spots. The mixed picture complicated policy prospects.

more_info.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Talmon Joseph Smith

title: Why the November Jobs Report Is Better Than It Looks
content: The number of jobs added was below expectations, but otherwise the report shows an economy on the right track.

title: Billions for Climate Protection Fuel New Debate: Who Deserves It Most
content: The $1 trillion infrastructure law funds programs that tend to favor wealthy, white communities — a test for Biden’s pledge to defend the most vulnerable against climate change.

title: A Slow-Motion Climate Disaster: The Spread of Barren Land
content: Brazil’s northeast, long a victim of droughts, is now effectively turning into a desert. The cause? Climate change and the landowners who are most affected.

more_info.byline: By Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama

title: Thefts, Always an Issue for Retailers, Become More Brazen
content: In recent months, robberies have been more visible, with several involving large groups rushing into stores and coming out with armloads of goods.

more_info.byline: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari

title: In Afghanistan, ‘Who Has the Guns Gets the Land’
content: A decades-long fight over land has been reinvigorated as Taliban leaders look to reward their fighters with property, even if that means evicting others.

more_info.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Yaqoob Akbary and Jim Huylebroek

title: What Happened to Amazon’s Bookstore?
content: A 2011 thriller was supposed to cost $15. One merchant listed it at $987, with a 17th-century publication date. That’s what happens in a marketplace where third-party sellers run wild.

title: Stabbed 20 Times by Her Husband, She Now Fights Laws Favoring Abusers
content: Shira Isakov, once a little-known Israeli working in advertising, has become a national force in the struggle to combat domestic violence and change the legal landscape on parental rights.

title: The Great ‘West Side Story’ Debate
content: With the Steven Spielberg film coming soon, three critics, a playwright and a theater historian weigh in on whether the musical deserves a new hearing — and how.

title: Samba, Cachaça and Pickled Eggs: ‘Dirty Feet’ Bars Are ‘Essence of Rio’
content: A cross between a dive bar and a greasy spoon, Rio de Janeiro’s beloved (and proudly filthy) hole-in-the wall joints are some of the most democratic spaces in a deeply unequal city.

title: Best TV Shows of 2021
content: From Bo Burnham to “We Are Lady Parts,” the best in television this year offered ingenuity, humor, defiance and hope.

title: English Teenager Finds Bronze Age Ax Using a Metal Detector
content: On her third day out with a metal detector, Milly Hardwick, 13, found a hoard of items from more than 3,000 years ago. “We were just laughing our heads off,” she said.
